title: at West Broadway and Franklin Street, to Southeast, Manhattan

text:
West Broadway, at the S. W. corner of Franklin Street (right), viewing across the open area identified as Finn Square, formed at the point of convergence by West Broadway and Varick Street. Ordinarily this location would be a portion of the latter thoroughfare, as it is apparently a continuation. The fact remains that both sides of the Square are classified as being West Broadway.

A one story tax-payer (No. 137 Franklin Street) is shown upon the former site of the Fifth Ward Museum. This was operated by an individual named "Riley". On exhibition there, included with other incunabula was the statue of William Pitt. The New York Historical Society possesses same today.

The New York Sun published a drawing of the old Hotel building in their series "Old New York in Pictures". This was No. 169, titled, "The Fifth Ward Museum Hotel in 1864".
The large building bearing the various signs is No. 139 Franklin Street, and adjoins the corner.

July 12, 1939

P. L. Sperr

West Broadway, at Finn Square, showing buildings on the east side, extending from Franklin (right, not seen) to White Street's. The 2½-story structure appearing at the left is at the N.W. corner of the latter thoroughfare, being No. 2 White Street. O'ershadowing same is the utilitarian New York Telephone Building at the convergence of Sixth Avenue South and Church Street.

Shown is the entrance to the west side line of the I.R.T. subway which runs along Varick Street.

May 19, 1939

P. L. Sperr
